steps.prompt: A new report shows model spread on regional impacts. How do you frame the story?

choices.label: ‘Scientists can’t agree — crisis of credibility’.
choices.feedback: Misleading: disagreement is normal and productive.

choices.label: Focus on the range of outcomes as guide.
choices.feedback: Accurate: spreads show what scientists know and don’t know.

choices.label: Highlight one model as most reliable.
choices.feedback: Risky: no single best model exists.

choices.label: Interview scientists to explain disagreements.
choices.feedback: Best practice: helps the public see how science learns from error.

steps.prompt: Readers ask why imperfect models should be trusted at all. How do you respond?

choices.label: Agreement across imperfect models is powerful.
Errors reveal how science improves.
choices.feedback: Exactly: failure is a source of learning.

steps.prompt: You’re assigned to report on a proposed geoengineering trial. How do you report it?

choices.label: Promote the trial as a quick fix.
choices.feedback: Misleading: geoengineering is no silver bullet.

choices.label: Report cautiously; emphasize small-scale and uncertainties.
Dismiss it entirely.
choices.feedback: Inaccurate: debate is ongoing and complex.

choices.label: Frame it as part of broader strategies.
choices.feedback: Yes: one of many tools under consideration.

steps.prompt: An editor asks why you included a weaker model’s results. Feature weaker models?

choices.label: Ignore weaker models completely.
choices.feedback: Risky: discarding them hides how science learns from diversity and error.

choices.label: Explain that scientists are studying these models.
choices.feedback: Best: shows the public that error-diagnosis is part of progress.

choices.label: Treat them as equal to top models.
choices.feedback: Misleading: not all models should be weighed the same in reporting.

choices.label: Average them in to avoid confusion.
choices.feedback: Problematic: averages can bury important differences.

end.summary: As a Journalist, you learned to report on uncertainty without sensationalism, highlight the value of agreement and disagreement, show why scientists study weaker models, and responsibly cover emerging technologies like geoengineering.
